Whether a managing agency could be regarded as business was considered by this Court in Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. The Government of Hyderabad , where the question arose with reference to assessment of excess profits tax on the remuneration received by managing agents, tax being leviable under that Act only on business income and it was held that it was business,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent from Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal where managing agency remuneration assessed as business income under Excess Profits Tax Act.

holdings.text: The word 'property' in s. 4(3)(i) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 includes business.

anchor.surface_text: The law must therefore be taken to be settled beyond controversy that managing agency is itself business. Then the question is whether that business can be held to be property within s. 4 3 i of the Act. Now property is a term of the widest import, and subject to any limitation or qualification which the context might require, it signifies every possible interest which a person can acquire, hold and enjoy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property is term of widest import including all interests; no restriction in s.4(3)(i); supported by Tribune Press and All India Spinners precedents; distinction from s.9 rejected.

holdings.text: Meaning of 'property' in s.4(3)(i) is not controlled by its use in s.9.

anchor.surface_text: a contention was raised that the word property must bear the same meaning both in ss. 9 and 4 3 i , that in s. 9 it was used in contradistinction to business which was dealt with under s. 10, and that therefore property in s. 4 3 i could not include business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects uniform meaning argument; s.4(3)(i) context independent; follows High Court in Tribune.

holdings.text: Managing agency, though an office involving services, is property capable of being held on trust.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No antithesis between service and business; offices like trusteeship are property (Angurbala, Shirur Mutt); managing agency profitable and alienable.

holdings.text: Precarious or terminable nature of managing agency does not prevent it from being property held on trust.

anchor.surface_text: In re The Tribune 1935 3 I.T.R. 246., the question was whether a trust created over the Tribune press and newspaper was for a charitable purpose as defined in s. 4(3)(i) of the Act. The majority of the learned Judges of the High Court took the view that the object of the trust was not wholly religious or charitable, and that accordingly the exemption under that section could not be claimed.

anchor.surface_text: Whether a managing agency could be regarded as business was considered by this Court in Lakshminarayan Ram Gopal and Son Ltd. v. The Government of Hyderabad , where the question arose with reference to assessment of excess profits tax on the remuneration received by managing agents, tax being leviable under that Act only on business income and it was held that it was business,
In the result, we remand the case to the High Court of Bombay for a fresh disposal of the reference on a consideration of the second question.

anchor.surface_text: The law must therefore be taken to be settled beyond controversy that managing agency is itself business. Then the question is whether that business can be held to be property within s. 4 3 i of the Act. Now property is a term of the widest import, and subject to any limitation or qualification which the context might require, it signifies every possible interest which a person can acquire, hold and enjoy.
In the result, we remand the case to the High Court of Bombay for a fresh disposal of the reference on a consideration of the second question.
